forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 6 weeks (≈41 days) until July 1, 2025 (Metaculus will check on/after that date).
forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — current conditions likely imply ≤51 listed direct destinations.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Regional security tensions persist and European carriers largely keep suspensions in place; MEA and Gulf/regional airlines maintain core routes but only a limited number of seasonal adds (e.g., a few Turkish leisure cities), leaving the total in the 35–50 range on flightsfrom.com by July 1.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: MEA plus regional/LCCs load a robust summer schedule: multiple Turkish leisure cities (AYT, BJV, ADB, TZX, etc.), Greek seasonal routes, Caucasus (EVN/TBS/possibly BUS), West Africa resumptions (e.g., ABJ/ACC/LOS), and several European resumptions (LHR/FRA/BRU/AMS/MRS/LYS). Combined, unique destinations exceed 51 by July 1.
forecast.rationale: Baseline: Beirut (BEY) is MEA’s hub and historically could support 50+ destinations in summer. However, since Oct 2023, many European carriers suspended BEY due to regional risk; tourism has been weak, and 2024–2025 tensions along the Israel–Lebanon border have persisted. Summer schedules are largely set by late May, so big last‑minute expansions are unlikely. A conservative, status‑quo‑weighted view is that MEA and regional carriers will sustain strong Middle East/Gulf/Iraq coverage (roughly 20–30 unique airports) plus a narrowed but nontrivial Europe/Caucasus/Turkey set (perhaps 15–20), which likely totals under 51. The main upside path is seasonal leisure: multiple Turkish coastal/cities, added Greek/Caucasus points, and any West Africa resumptions (diaspora demand) or resumed UK/German/French secondary cities. These could push the count over 51 if several materialize simultaneously. The cited articles point to weak tourism demand and disruption risks, consistent with a cautious stance. Research assistant: no additional info provided, so I’m leaning more on structural factors (conflict risk, airline insurance/operational posture, schedule lead times) and historical patterns. Why not higher: Persistent security/insurance constraints and subdued inbound tourism reduce the odds of broad European resumptions by July 1. Why not lower: MEA’s hub role, resilient outbound/diaspora demand, and seasonal leisure to Turkey/Caucasus could materially lift the count. Updaters: I’d raise the probability if current flightsfrom.com already shows 48–50+ destinations, or if credible announcements confirm multiple European resumptions and Turkish/Greek seasonals; I’d lower it if further escalation triggers new suspensions or if current listings are only in the mid‑30s to low‑40s.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will there be greater than 51 direct flight destinations from Beirut, Lebanon on July 1, 2025?

Question background:
Catholic News Agency: [Lebanon will soon have its own ‘camino,’ once traveled by Christ and the Romans](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/263055/caminos-lebanon-new-initiative-is-designed-to-revive-religious-tourism-in-the-country) | Travel and Tour World: [Lebanon’s Hospitality Sector In Peril: Rising Costs And Low Tourism Threaten Survival](https://www.travelandtourworld.com/news/article/lebanons-hospitality-sector-in-peril-rising-costs-and-low-tourism-threaten-survival/) | The New Arab: [Summer canceIled: Israeli attack hits Lebanon tourism hopes](https://www.newarab.com/news/summer-canceiled-israeli-attack-hits-lebanon-tourism-hopes)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if there are greater than 51 direct flight destinations listed at the [All scheduled direct (non-stop) flights from Beirut (BEY)](https://www.flightsfrom.com/BEY) tracker when checked by Metaculus on or after July 1, 2025.




Your research assistant's report says:
No additional information available.

Today is 2025-05-21.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
